displacement=*{{convert|626.115|t|LT|0}} standard *{{convert|700.54|t|LT|0}} normal (surfaced) *{{convert|859.69|t|LT|0}} normal (submerged) |Ship length={{convert|60.18|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref name=ISI/> |Ship beam={{convert|6.454|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref name=ISI/> |Ship draft={{convert|4.709|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref name=ISI/> |Ship power=*{{convert|1350|hp|lk=in|abbr=on}} (diesels)<ref name=m2/> *{{convert|800|hp|abbr=on}} (electric motors)<ref name=m2/> |Ship propulsion=*[[Diesel-electric]] *2 × [[Cantieri Riuniti dell'Adriatico|CRDA]] [[diesel engine]]s *2 × [[Cantieri Riuniti dell'Adriatico|CRDA]] electric engines |Ship speed=*{{convert|14|kn|lk=in}} surfaced<ref name=ISI/> *{{convert|7.5|kn}} submerged<ref name=ISI/> |Ship range=*{{convert|5200|nmi|abbr=on|lk=in}} at {{convert|8|kn}} surfaced<ref name=ISI/> *{{convert|74|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|4|kn}} submerged<ref name=ISI/> |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth={{convert|80|m|ft|abbr=on}}<ref name=ISI/> |Ship complement=44 (4 officers + 40 non-officers and sailors) |Ship armament=*6 × {{convert|533|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s (4 bow, 2 stern)<ref name=ISI/> *1 × [[Škoda 10 cm K10#OTO 100.2F47 History|{{convert|100|mm|in|abbr=on|0}} / 47 caliber]] [[deck gun]]<ref name=ISI/> *2 x 1 - [[Breda Model 1931 Machine Gun|{{convert|13.2|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] [[anti-aircraft gun]]s<ref name=ISI/> |Ship notes= }} |}
'''Italian submarine ''Corallo''''' was a {{sclass-|Perla|submarine|2}} built for the [[Royal Italian Navy]] (''Regia Marina'') during the 1930s. She was named after a gemstone [[Precious coral|Coral]].
==Design and description== The ''Perla''-class submarines were essentially repeats of the preceding {{sclass-|Sirena|submarine|4}}. The modifications that were made compared to the boats of the previous series were mostly of upgrade nature. Among them were enlargement of the false tower at the top, more modern engines, installation of a radiogoniometer that could be controlled from inside the ship. Improvements and the installation of new air conditioning equipment meant a slight increase in displacement, and increase in the fuel stowage also increased the autonomy of these boats compared to the previous series.<ref name=ISI1>Pollina, p.155</ref> Their designed full load [[Displacement (ship)|displacement]] was {{convert|695|t|LT|sp=us}} surfaced and {{convert|855|t|LT|sp=us}} submerged, but varied somewhat depending on the boat and the builder. The submarines were {{convert|197|ft|6|in|m|sp=us}} long, had a [[beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|21|ft|m|sp=us}} and a [[draft (hull)|draft]] of {{convert|15|ft|m|sp=us}} to {{convert|15|ft|5|in|m|sp=us}}.<ref name=b4>Bagnasco, p. 153</ref><ref name=ISI>Pollina, pp.152-153</ref>
For surface running, the boats were powered by two [[diesel engine]]s, each driving one [[propeller shaft]] with overall power of {{convert|675|-|750|hp|abbr=on|lk=in|0|adj=on}}.<ref name=b4/> When submerged each propeller was driven by a {{convert|400|hp|0|adj=on}} [[electric motor]]. They could reach {{convert|14|kn|lk=in}} on the surface and {{convert|7.5|kn}} underwater. On the surface, the ''Perla'' class had a range of {{convert|5200|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|8|kn}}, submerged, they had a range of {{convert|74|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|4|kn}}.<ref name=b4>Bagnasco, p. 153</ref><ref name=ISI>Pollina, pp.152-153</ref>
The boats were armed with six internal {{convert|53.3|cm|in|1|abbr=on|sp=us}} [[torpedo tube]]s, four in the bow and two in the stern. One reload torpedo was carried for each tube, for a total of twelve. They were also armed with one [[Škoda 10 cm K10#OTO 100.2F47 History|{{convert|100|mm|in|abbr=on|0}}]] [[deck gun]] for combat on the surface. The light anti-aircraft armament consisted of one or two pairs of [[Breda Model 1931 Machine Gun|{{convert|13.2|mm|in|abbr=on}}]] machine guns.<ref name=ISI/>
==Construction and career== ''Corallo'' was built by [[Cantieri Riuniti dell' Adriatico|CRDA]] at their shipyard in [[Monfalcone]], laid on 1 October 1935, [[Ship naming and launching|launched]] on 2 August 1936 and completed on 26 September 1936.<ref name=ISI>Pollina, pp.152-153</ref>
After delivery, ''Corallo'' was assigned to the 34th Squadron (III Submarine Group) based at [[Messina]]. After a brief training, she carried out a long endurance cruise in the [[Dodecanese]] and the [[Adriatic]]. In 1937 she carried out a training campaign, followed by another one in 1938. On October 15, 1938 she was temporarily assigned to Flotilla Submarine school. In 1939 ''Corallo'' returned to active duty, and was assigned to the 72nd Squadron (VII Submarine Group) based at [[Cagliari]] where she remained until the end of her career.<ref name="m2">[http://www.mucamonfalcone.it/aspx/ViewProspettazioneNave.aspx?idCon=1221&idAmb=149&idMenu=-1&liv=0&order=0&tp=vArchivioNavi&cosaCerca=corallo ''Corallo'' at Monfalcone Naval Museum]</ref>
[[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]]'s entry into [[World War II]] found ''Corallo'' at [[Monfalcone]] undergoing repairs and maintenance which were finished in late August 1940. On September 3, 1940 ''Corallo'', under command of captain Loris Albanese, was sent to patrol an area 60 miles south of [[Crete]], between [[Gavdos|Gaudo]] and [[Alexandria]]. At 18:00 on September 17 ''Corallo'' sighted in the position {{Coord|33|34|N|25|34|E}} a zigzagging British column heading towards [[Alexandria]]. The British force was made up of the aircraft carrier {{HMS|Illustrious|87|6}}, battleship {{HMS|Valiant|1914|6}} escorted by five destroyers returning to [[Alexandria]] after bombarding [[Derna, Libya|Derna]] and [[Benghazi]]. At 18:30 ''Corallo'' launched two torpedoes from 1,500 meters against {{HMS|Illustrious|87|6}} and immediately dove down to 80 meters <ref name=g1>Giorgerini, p. 244</ref><ref name=m2/>. After 75 seconds two loud explosions were heard, but no ship, however, was hit. ''Corallo'' was then subjected to depth charge attacks by the destroyers which went on for 3 hours.<ref name=m2/> The submarine suffered some damage which impaired her operational efficiency, and two crew members died in the attack. Since the damage to submarine could not be repaired by means available at sea, ''Corallo'' was forced to interrupt her mission and headed to [[Tobruk]] which she reached on September 18, 1940 <ref name=g2>Giorgerini, p. 245</ref>.
On November 5, 1940 ''Corallo'' and four other submarines ({{ship|Italian submarine|Topazio||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Fratelli Bandiera||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Pier Capponi||2}} and {{ship|Italian submarine|Goffredo Mameli||2}}) were deployed about 90 miles south-east of [[Malta]] with the task of intercepting a British convoy, part of Operation "Coat". ''Corallo'' and other submarines formed a barrier with a 20 to 30 miles spacing between them. ''Corallo'', however, did not detect any enemy vessels <ref name=g3>Giorgerini, p. 267</ref><ref name=bertke4>Bertke, p.108</ref>.
On January 21, 1941 ''Corallo'' and {{ship|Italian submarine|Diaspro||2}} patrolled off the northern Tunisian coast.<ref name=bertke>Bertke, p.242</ref> ''Corallo'' had to abort her mission almost immediately due to a failure, and the submarine had to return to the base.<ref name="x2">[http://www.xmasgrupsom.com/Sommergibili/corallo.htm ''Corallo'' on XMasGrupSom]</ref>
In February 1941 she was on patrol north of Cape Bougaroun, but engine problems forced the submarine to return to the base.
In April 1941 she patrolled south of [[Sardinia]], but her mission was cut short again, this time because of the adverse weather conditions.<ref name=x2/>
In May 1941 she patrolled around 50 miles west of the island of [[Galite Islands|La Galite]] without any sightings.<ref name=x2/>
In July 1941 ''Corallo'' was involved in another uneventful patrol southwest of [[Sardinia]].<ref name=x2/>
In October 1941 she was posted off [[Cap Zebib]], but still without success.<ref name=x2/>
On November 3, 1941 ''Corallo'' under command of captain Andreani was deployed west of [[Malta]] as a protective screen for a large Italian "Beta" convoy travelling to [[Libya]]. Her job was to detect and report any British naval movements west of Malta, and attack the sighted ships when possible. On November 9, 1941 the "Beta" convoy was intercepted and destroyed by British Force K in the [[Battle of the Duisburg Convoy]]. Force K managed to leave [[Malta]] without ''Corallo'' being able to detect it since it did not pass through her area of operation, but rather through the one controlled by {{ship|Italian submarine|Settembrini||2}}. At sunset, the submarine left her assigned area and moved to her new area of operations off [[Algeria]] and [[Tunisia]].
In January 1942 she patrolled between [[Malta]] and [[Capo Passero]].<ref name=x2/>
In March 1942 ''Corallo'' again patrolled off [[Malta]].<ref name=x2/>
In April 1942 ''Coralllo'' was sent to patrol off [[Cape Bon]]. At 4:10 on April 28, 1942 off [[Annaba|Bona]], ''Corallo'' stopped Tunisian sailboats ''Dar es Salaam'' (138 GRT) and ''Tunis'' (41 GRT). The boats carried a Vichy France flag, but didn't have a special permit allowing them to sail. ''Corallo'' took their crew on board, thirteen men in total, then sank the sailboats with gunfire in the position {{coord|37|01|N|11|09|E}}. <ref name=g4>Giorgerini, p. 322</ref><ref name=m2/>
In May and June 1942 she patrolled east of the island of [[Galite Islands|La Galite]]. At 2:00 on June 7, 1942, ''Corallo'' stopped another Tunisian sailboat ''Hady M'Hammed'' (26 GRT). Believing the boat was carrying materials on behalf of the Allies, captain Adreani ordered the crew of the sailboat (6 men) to abandon ship, took them prisoners and then sank the sailboat with gunfire in the position {{coord|37|24|N|09|10|E}}.<ref name=m2/> ''Corallo'' then received an order to patrol another area northwest of [[Algiers]]. Upon return to the base, a new commander, captain Guido Guidi, was appointed.
On June 11, 1942 the submarine was sent along with four other submarines ({{ship|Italian submarine|Onice||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Ascianghi||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Aradam||2}} and {{ship|Italian submarine|Dessiè||2}}) to patrol the triangle between [[Malta]], [[Pantelleria]] and [[Lampedusa]] with the task of interception of a British convoy, part of Operation ''Harpoon''. ''Corallo'' did not, however, sight any enemy ships <ref name=g5>Giorgerini, p. 326</ref>.
In October 1942 she was sent to patrol an area south of the [[Balearic Islands]].<ref name=x2/>
In November 1942 after the launch of [[Operation Torch]] she was deployed to patrol an area off [[Bizerta]]. ''Corallo'' also penetrated into [[Skikda|Philippeville]] harbor, but there were no ships to attack.<ref name=x2/>
In early December she was deployed together with {{ship|Italian submarine|Alagi||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Argento||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Bronzo||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Galatea||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Porfido||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Volframio||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Mocenigo||2}}, {{ship|Italian submarine|Diaspro||2}} and {{ship|Italian submarine|Malachite||2}} in the western Mediterranean, as a defensive screen protecting Axis convoys to [[Tunis]].
On December 10, 1942 ''Corallo'' sailed from [[Cagliari]] to patrol an area between [[Annaba|Bona]] and [[Bizerta]] with a task of trying to penetrate [[Bougie]] harbor during the night of December 13 and destroying any ships she would have found there. After the departure, ''Corallo'' was never heard from again.<ref name=m2/>
After the end of the war, from British records, it was established that on the night of December 13, 1942, ''Corallo'' 14 miles from [[Bougie]], was spotted and attacked by four British escorts ({{HMS|Enchantress|L56|6}}, {{HMS|Fleetwood|U47|6}}, {{HMS|Velox|D34|6}}, {{HMS|Venomous|D75|6}}) from the KMS-4 convoy, sailing from [[Gibraltar]] to [[Algiers]]. ''Corallo'' was depth charged, damaged and forced to surface. At this point, according to some sources, ''Corallo'' tried to engage {{HMS|Enchantress|L56|6}} with her deck gun, but the British sloop accelerated and rammed the submarine. While {{HMS|Enchantress|L56|6}} suffered serious collision damage even to her inner structures, ''Corallo'' had the worst of it, and sunk with all hands (commander Guidi, 5 officers, and 43 other crew members) in the position {{coord|36|58|N|05|07|E}}.<ref name=m2/>
== Notes == {{reflist|30em}}
== References == *{{cite book|last=Bagnasco |first=Erminio |title=Submarines of World War Two |year=1977 |publisher=Naval Institute Press |location=Annapolis, Maryland |isbn=0-87021-962-6}} *{{cite book|title=Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1922–1946|editor1-last=Chesneau|editor1-first=Roger|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=Greenwich, UK|year=1980|isbn=0-85177-146-7}} *{{cite book|last=Rohwer|first=Jürgen|title=Chronology of the War at Sea 1939-1945: The Naval History of World War Two|publisher=Naval Institute Press|location=Annapolis, Maryland|year=2005|edition=Third Revised|isbn=1-59114-119-2|authorlink=Jürgen Rohwer}} *{{cite book|last=Giorgerini|first=Giorgio|title=Uomini sul fondo. Storia del sommergibilismo italiano dalle origini ad oggi|publisher=Mondadori|year=2002|edition=Second|isbn=8804505370}} *{{cite book|last=Pollina|first=Paolo|title=I Sommergibili Italiani 1895-1962|publisher=SMM|year=1963|location=Rome, Italy}} *{{cite book|last1=Bertke |first1=Donald |last2=Smith |first2=Gordon |last3=Kindell |first3=Don |title=World War II Sea War, Volume 3: The Royal Navy is Bloodied in the Mediterranean |year=2012 |publisher= Bertke Publications |isbn= 978-1937470012}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder | birthname=James Anthony Traficant Jr. | image name=James Traficant 105th Congress 1997.jpg | state=[[Ohio]] | district=[[Ohio's 17th congressional district|17th]] | birth_place=[[Youngstown, Ohio]] | birth_date={{birth date|1941|5|8}} | death_place=[[Poland, Ohio]] | death_date={{nowrap|{{death date and age|2014|9|27|1941|5|8}}}} | death_cause=Injuries sustained in a farming accident | spouse=Patricia "Tish" Choppa Traficant | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (1981–2002)
Independent (2002–2014) | preceded=[[Lyle Williams]] | succeeded=[[Tim Ryan (politician)|Tim Ryan]] | term_start=January 3, 1985 | term_end = July 24, 2002 }} '''James Anthony Traficant Jr.''' (May 8, 1941 – September 27, 2014) was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]], and later independent, politician and member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[Ohio]]. He represented the [[Ohio's 17th congressional district|17th Congressional District]], which centered on his hometown of [[Youngstown, Ohio|Youngstown]] and included parts of three counties in northeast Ohio's [[Mahoning Valley]]. He was [[Expulsion from the United States Congress|expelled from the House]] after being convicted of taking bribes, filing false tax returns, [[Racket (crime)|racketeering]] and forcing his aides to perform chores at his farm in Ohio and houseboat in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web|title=Traficant guilty of bribery, racketeering|url=http://www.cnn.com/2002/LAW/04/11/traficant.trial|website=cnn.com|date=12 April 2002}} He was sentenced to prison and released on September 2, 2009, after serving a seven-year sentence. Traficant died on September 27, 2014, as the result of injuries sustained in an accident that had occurred several days earlier when his tractor flipped over as he was driving it into his barn. ==Early life, education, and career== Born into a working-class [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] family in [[Youngstown, Ohio]], Traficant was the son of Agnes (''née'' Farkas) and James Anthony Traficant Sr.{{cite web|last=Jerome |first=Richard |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20137670,00.html |title=To the Bitter End – Crime & Courts |publisher=People.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-27}}[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VRFJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TYMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3191,5487854&dq=agnes+farkas+traficant&hl=en Mass, Parties Fete Traficants on Anniversary], Youngstown Vindicator, June 15, 1977 He was of mostly Italian and Slovak ancestry.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MyIoy7F9uEoC&pg=PA221 |title=Buy American: The Untold Story of Economic Nationalism – Dana Frank – Google Books |publisher=Books.google.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-03-27}} Traficant graduated from [[Cardinal Mooney High School (Youngstown, Ohio)|Cardinal Mooney High School]] in 1959 and the [[University of Pittsburgh]] in 1963. He played [[quarterback]] for Pitt's [[American football|football]] team, and his teammates included [[Mike Ditka]].Milan Simonich, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, [http://old.post-gazette.com/nation/20020412traf0412p3.asp Rep. James Traficant: 'He's perceived ... to have almost magical powers'], April 12, 2002 Traficant was [[1963 NFL draft|drafted]] in the NFL's twentieth round (276th overall) by the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] in 1963, and tried out for the Steelers and the [[Oakland Raiders]] of the [[American Football League]], but did not play professionally.Jack Snell, ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'', [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19630620&id=rn1IAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JmwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5951,3273704 Steelers Sign all but Four Draft Choices: Pitt's Traficant Still Undecided], June 20, 1963United Press International, Beaver County Times, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=19630727&id=88QuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=T9sFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2434,4311310 Steelers Cut Jim Traficant], July 27, 1963 He later obtained a master's degree from the University of Pittsburgh (1973) and another from [[Youngstown State University]] (1976).U.S. Government Printing Office, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TFI16kHFJ-MC&q=traficant+%22university+of+pittsburgh%22+1973&dq=traficant+%22university+of+pittsburgh%22+1973&hl=en&sa=X&ei=97--U93WD621sATQ7IHQBQ&ved=0CFcQ6AEwBw 1993–1994 Official Congressional Directory], 1993, page 238 At the start of his career, Traficant worked as consumer finance director for the Youngstown Community Action Program. He taught courses on drug and alcohol dependency and recovery at Youngstown State University and [[Kent State University]], as well as lecturing on drug and alcohol abuse for colleges and government agencies outside Ohio. In addition, Traficant taught at the Ohio Peace Officer Training Academy.U.S. Government Printing Office, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zRw5AQAAMAAJ&q=traficant+youngstown+community+action+program&dq=traficant+youngstown+community+action+program&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZsC-U7WJG5TQsQSqt4C4Cg&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAQ Congressional Directory], 1999, page 213 He was the executive director of the Mahoning County Drug Program from 1971 to 1981, and Sheriff of [[Mahoning County]] from 1981 to 1985. While serving as sheriff, Traficant made national headlines by refusing to execute foreclosure orders on several unemployed homeowners, many of whom had been left out of work by the recent closures of steel mills. This endeared him to the local population, which was dealing with a declining economy following the closures and relocations of steel making and steel-associated businesses.{{cite news | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A00E6D81531F93BA15751C0A9649C8B63&st=cse&sq=peyko&scp=1 | first = Mark C | last = Peyko |title = Notes From Youngstown: The Angry Voice of a City Left Behind | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2008-03-24 | date=February 28, 2002}} In 1983, he was charged with racketeering for accepting bribes. Traficant, who represented himself in the criminal trial, argued that he accepted the bribes only as part of his own alleged secret undercover investigation into corruption. Traficant was acquitted of the charges, becoming the only person ever to win a [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act]] (RICO) case while representing himself.Scott A. Frisch, Sean Q. Kelly, [https://books.google.com/books?id=QA1Mx_51nbUC&pg=PA170&dq=traficant+sheriff+acquitted+fbi&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fsG-U5H6N-jQsATV_YHIBQ&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=traficant%20sheriff%20acquitted%20fbi&f=false Committee Assignment Politics in the U.S. House of Representatives], 2006, page 170Congressional Quarterly, Traficant Responds Defiantly to Corruption Indictment, Volume 59, 2001, page 989 Publicity from the RICO trial increased Traficant's local visibility. He was elected as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to Congress from Ohio's 17th District, defeating [[Lyle Williams]], a three-term [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] incumbent. He was [[Ohio's 17th congressional district|reelected eight times]] without serious opposition. ==U.S. House of Representatives== While in Congress, Traficant was a supporter of [[Immigration reduction in the United States|immigration reduction]],"[http://profiles.numbersusa.com/improfile.php3?DistSend=OH&VIPID=647 All Immigration Votes of Representative James Traficant]." [[NumbersUSA]]. Accessed January 6, 2008. and a strong opponent of [[illegal immigration]]. In the controversy surrounding the [[Bob Dornan#Defeat|defeat of Congressman Bob Dornan]] (R-CA) by Democrat [[Loretta Sanchez]], Traficant was the only Democratic member of Congress who advocated a new election, due to Dornan's allegations of voting in that race by undocumented immigrants. The allegations went unproven, and a new election was not held. Traficant's major legislative accomplishment in the House was the adoption of some of his proposals to constrain enforcement activities by the [[Internal Revenue Service]] against delinquent taxpayers. After the Republicans took control of the House in 1995, Traficant tended to vote more often with the Republicans than with his own party. On the issue of abortion, Traficant voted with the position of the [[National Right to Life Committee]] 95% of the time in the 105th Congress, and 100% of the time in the 106th and 107th Congresses. However, he voted against all four articles of impeachment against [[Bill Clinton]]. After he voted for Republican [[Dennis Hastert]] for [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] in 2001, the Democrats stripped him of his seniority and refused to give him any committee assignments. Because the Republicans did not assign him to any committees either, Traficant became the first member of the House of Representatives in over a century—outside the top leadership—to lack a single committee assignment.{{cite web|first=Katherine |last=Rizzo |agency=Associated Press |url=http://lubbockonline.com/stories/050801/upd_075-2220.shtml |title=Armey: GOP doesn't want Traficant |publisher=Lubbockonline.com|date=2001-05-08 |accessdate=2013-03-27}} ===Defense of John Demjanjuk=== Traficant championed the unpopular cause of [[John Demjanjuk]], a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]]-born autoworker from [[Seven Hills, Ohio|Seven Hills]], who had been convicted in [[Israel]] and sentenced to hang for having been the brutal [[Internment#Concentration camp|concentration camp]] guard [[Ivan the Terrible (Treblinka guard)|Ivan the Terrible]].{{cite web |url=http://jta.org/news/article/2009/10/30/1008850/traficant-says-he-will-testify-for-demjanjuk |title=Traficant says he would testify for Demjanjuk |publisher=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] |date=October 30, 2009 |accessdate=October 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130415083224/http://jta.org/news/article/2009/10/30/1008850/traficant-says-he-will-testify-for-demjanjuk |archivedate=April 15, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} For almost a decade, Traficant (along with [[Pat Buchanan]])[[Pat Buchanan|Buchanan, Pat]] (2011-05-13) [http://www.amconmag.com/blog/2011/05/12/demjanjuk-convicted-by-the-kgb/ Demjanjuk Convicted – By the KGB], ''[[The American Conservative]]'' insisted that Demjanjuk had been denied a fair trial, and been the victim of mistaken identity; in 1993 the [[Supreme Court of Israel]] overturned the conviction, on the basis of doubt. Demjanjuk was later deported to Germany on May 11, 2009, after the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] refused to overturn his deportation order. Demjanjuk was tried and convicted by a German criminal court of being an accessory to murder, but died before the German Appellate Court could hear his case, thereby voiding the conviction.{{cite news |author=Aderet, Ofer |title=News article: Convicted Nazi criminal Demjanjuk deemed innocent in Germany over technicality |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=March 23, 2012 |accessdate=July 4, 2012 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/convicted-nazi-criminal-demjanjuk-deemed-innocent-in-germany-over-technicality-1.420280}}. [[Drake Caggiula]] was later not charged for a similar offense by the German government. ===Defense of Arthur Rudolph=== Following [[Pat Buchanan]]'s recommendation to reconsider the denaturalization of former Nazi and [[NASA]] scientist [[Arthur Rudolph]], who had been brought to the United States under [[Operation Paperclip]], Traficant spoke to the Friends of Arthur Rudolph, an organization based in [[Huntsville, Alabama]].{{cite book |last=Laney |first=Monique |date=2015 |title=German Rocketeers in the Heart of Dixie: Making Sense of the Nazi Past During the Civil Rights Era |location=New Haven and London |publisher=Yale University Press |pages=173–174 |isbn=978-0-300-19803-4}} He argued that denaturalization had happened because of a "powerful Jewish lobby" influencing Congress. He added that it was a violation of a United States citizen's civil rights, and he suggested that Rudolph return to the United States nonetheless. Additionally, he "introduced a resolution in Congress [...] calling for an investigation into the [[Office of Scientific Intelligence|OSI]]'s handling of Rudolph's case." Meanwhile, in 1990, Traficant had planned to meet Rudolph in [[Niagara Falls]], on the Canadian–American border; however, Rudolph was arrested by immigration officials in [[Toronto]], and the meeting never occurred. ===Trial and expulsion=== In 2002, Traficant was indicted on federal corruption charges for taking campaign funds for personal use. Again, he opted to represent himself, insisting that the trial was part of a vendetta against him dating back to his 1983 trial. After a two-month federal trial, on April 11, 2002, he was convicted of 10 felony counts including bribery, racketeering and tax evasion. Per House rules, he lost his right to vote on legislation pending an investigation by the [[United States House Committee on Ethics]]. Eventually, the House Ethics Committee recommended that Traficant be expelled from Congress. On July 24 the House voted to expel him by a 420–1 vote.{{cite web|title=In the Matter of Representative James A. Traficant Jr.|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/F?r107:196:./temp/~r107VGqzPr:e164602:| work=U.S. House of Representatives| date=24 July 2002}} The sole vote against expulsion was Rep. [[Gary Condit]], who at the time was in the midst of a scandal of his own and had been defeated in his reelection primary.{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2002/roll346.xml|title=Final Vote Results for Roll Call 346 | last=Trandahl | first=Jeff | date=July 24, 2002 | work=clerk.house.gov | publisher=Clerk of the United States House of Representatives | accessdate=March 22, 2012}} Traficant was the first representative to be expelled since [[Michael Myers (politician)|Michael Myers]]'s expulsion in 1980 as a result of the [[Abscam]] scandal. After his expulsion, Traficant ran as an independent candidate for another term in the House while incarcerated at the [[United States Penitentiary, Allenwood]].{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/08/05/traficant.prison/|title=Traficant arrives at federal prison|date=2002-08-06|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2009-11-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010204322/http://archives.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/08/05/traficant.prison/|archivedate=October 10, 2009|df=mdy-all}} He received 28,045 votes, or 15 percent, and became one of only a handful of individuals in the history of the United States to run for a federal office from prison. The election was won by one of his former aides, [[Tim Ryan (politician)|Tim Ryan]]. == Prison and later life == === Incarceration === Traficant entered the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Allenwood]], on August 6, 2002,{{Cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/08/05/traficant.prison/index.html |title=Traficant arrives at federal prison |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=August 6, 2002 |accessdate=2018-07-08}} with the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] ID # 31213-060."[http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&FirstName=James&Middle=&LastName=Traficant&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=0&y=0 JAMES A TRAFICANT JR]." [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]]. Retrieved on May 29, 2010. He served his first seventeen months at Allenwood. Shortly after his arrival, he was put in [[solitary confinement]] for incitement to riot after he told a guard, "People can't hear you. Speak up."{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,549164,00.html|title=Exclusive: Traficant – 'I Was a Target. ... I Must Have Been Doing Something Right'|last=Van Susteren|first=Greta|date=2009-09-10|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=2009-11-13}} During the seven years of his incarceration, Traficant refused any visitors, saying that he didn't want anyone to see him. He was released on September 2, 2009, at age 68, and was subject to three years of [[probation]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cantonrep.com/ohio/x1595417268/Ex-congressman-Traficant-freed |title=Ex-congressman Traficant freed |last=Merchant |first=Norman |date=2009-09-02 |accessdate=2009-09-29 |agency=Associated Press |work=Canton Rep}} While in prison, Traficant received support from [[David Duke]], who urged visitors to his personal website to donate to his personal fund. Duke posted a letter written by Traficant stating that he was targeted by the [[United States Department of Justice]] for, among other things, defending [[John Demjanjuk]]. Traficant also claimed, in the letter, that he knew facts about "[[Waco siege|Waco]], [[Ruby Ridge]], [[Pan Am Flight 103]], [[Jimmy Hoffa]] and the [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|John F. Kennedy assassination]]", which he may divulge in the future. Author [[Michael Collins Piper]], who initially helped circulate Traficant's letter, said that "There's stuff I've written about Traficant that's showing up in places I don't even know. It's like (six) degrees of separation with the Internet now," and denied that Traficant had any direct connections to Duke.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribtoday.com/page/content.detail/id/526652.html?nav=5021|title=White nationalists, conspiracy theorists join Traficant’s cause|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901054106/http://www.tribtoday.com/page/content.detail/id/526652.html?nav=5021|first=Bill|last=Rodgers|date=August 30, 2009|work=[[Tribune Chronicle]]|archivedate=September 1, 2009|accessdate=January 15, 2017}} === Release === Traficant was released from prison on September 2, 2009. On September 6, 2009, 1200 supporters welcomed him home at a banquet with an [[Elvis impersonator]], and a Traficant lookalike contest. "Welcome home Jimbo" was printed on T-shirts. "I think it's time to tell the FBI and the IRS that this is our country and we're tired—tired of the pressure, tired of the political targeting, tired of a powerful central government that is crippling America," he said. He also said he was considering running for his old seat in Congress. Traficant signed a limited, three-month contract to work as a part-time weekend [[talk radio]] host for [[Cleveland]] news/talk station [[WTAM]] in January 2010. His contract permitted him to quit if he chose to run for office.{{cite web|url=http://www.vindy.com/news/2010/jan/05/traficant-lands-a-part-time-job-on-radio/?newswatch |title=Traficant lands a part-time job on radio |publisher=Vindy.com |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2013-03-27}} On November 2, 2009, a column by Traficant in the [[American Free Press]] continued his defense of the accused concentration camp guard John Demjanjuk.{{cite news |url=http://www.adl.org/main_Extremism/jim_traficant_writes_afp_column.htm |title=Former Congressman Traficant to Contribute Column to Anti-Semitic Newspaper |publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]] |date=November 2, 2009 |accessdate=October 5, 2012}} [[Michael Collins Piper]] an AFP writer—who authored ''Target: Traficant, The Untold Story''{{cite book |last1=Piper |first1=Michael |authorlink=Michael Collins Piper |title=Target: Traficant: the outrageous inside story of how the Justice Department, the Israeli lobby and the American mass media conspired to set up and take down Congressman Jim Traficant |location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=[[American Free Press]] |year=2005 |isbn=0981808611}} {{ISBN|978-0981808611}} – previously defended Traficant against his accusers. === 2010 congressional campaign === In September 2010, Traficant was certified to run for the same seat he held before his expulsion, and said that his platform would be to repeal the [[Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ohio.com/news/break_news/92681999.html|title=Traficant files petitions to be candidate for Akron congressional district|accessdate=May 3, 2010}} Traficant lost the election to his former aide [[Tim Ryan (politician)|Tim Ryan]], to whom he lost an earlier race in 2002, in which Traficant ran as an independent from his prison cell.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/07/us/the-2002-elections-midwest-ohio.html|title=The 2002 Elections: Midwest; Ohio|date=2002-11-07|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2013-05-20 | first1=Nichole M. | last1=Christian | first2=John H. | last2=Cushman Jr | first3=Sherri | last3=Day | first4=Sam | last4=Dillon | first5=Neil A. | last5=Lewis | first6=Robert | last6=Pear | first7=Terry | last7=Pristin | first8=Philip | last8=Shenon | first9=Jacques | last9=Steinberg }} Traficant received 30,556 votes, or 16%. == Post-prison life == After his release from prison, he was featured as a guest speaker at a [[Tea Party protests|Tea Party protest]] in [[Columbiana, Ohio]], among other events affiliated with [[right-wing politics|conservatism]].{{cite web|url=http://www.business-journal.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=1&twindow=&mad=&sdetail=14598&wpage=1&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1711&hn=business-journal&he=.com|title=Traficant Draws Cheers at TEA Party|accessdate=September 16, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1209/31066.html|title=Jim Traficant: 'I'm going to run'|accessdate=December 30, 2009}} Traficant began a grassroots campaign in July 2014, "Project Freedom USA",{{cite web|url=http://www.projectfreedomusa.com|title=Project Freedom USA|accessdate=September 27, 2014}} to, among other things, put people pressure on Congress to get rid of the IRS and "divorce" the Federal Reserve.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nuCeTfo-cac|title=Traficant launches Project Freedom|work=YouTube|accessdate=September 28, 2014}} ==Accident and death== Traficant was injured in an accident at his farm on September 23, 2014. A tractor he was driving into a [[Pole building framing|pole barn]] flipped over and trapped him underneath. Traficant was taken to Salem Regional Medical Center in [[Salem, Ohio]], then airlifted to St. Elizabeth's Health Center in Youngstown. On the evening of September 24, his wife described him as "sedated and not doing well."{{cite news |first= Sabina |last= Eaton |title= Ex. Rep. Jim Traficant is seriously injured in tractor accident |work= Cleveland Plain Dealer |date= September 24, 2014 |accessdate= September 25, 2014 |url= http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2014/09/ex_rep_jim_traficant_reported.html}} By September 26, via news reports and statements from attorney and family spokesman Heidi Hanni, it was learned that the family was awaiting the doctors' assessment; there was no word as to whether or not Traficant had suffered a heart attack, but he was still unconscious and was being sedated for pain and other reasons. A number of longtime family friends, including Linda Kovachik, a former congressional aide to Traficant, told ''[[The Vindicator]]'' that it is believed Traficant had a heart attack, causing the tractor accident.{{cite web|url=http://www.vindy.com/news/2014/sep/27/traficant-remains-critical-respirator-re/|title=Youngstown News, Former congressman no longer on respirator, still unconscious|work=Vindy.com|accessdate=September 28, 2014}} A text message was sent out Friday evening September 26 by Jim Condit Jr., the Constitution Party candidate for Ohio's 8th congressional district and a close friend who had been traveling with Traficant to help promote Project Freedom USA. The text message stated that "the machines were disconnected at 2:00 p.m. (Friday). He is still breathing. Thousands are praying." On September 27, 2014, Traficant died at a hospice in [[Poland, Ohio]], aged 73.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-james-traficant-20140928-story.html|title=James Traficant obituary: Colorful, expelled and jailed ex-congressman dies – LA Times|date=September 27, 2014|work=latimes.com|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.wfmj.com/story/26643168/james-a-traficant-jr-dead-at-age-73 |title=James A. Traficant Jr. dead at age 73. |publisher=[[WFMJ-TV]] |date=September 27, 2014 |accessdate=September 27, 2014}} By September 29, Traficant's body had been buried in an undisclosed location after the family had a private funeral, and announced that there would be no public funeral for him.[http://www.wfmj.com/story/26650681/no-public-funeral-for-jim-traficant No public funeral for Jim Traficant] [[WFMJ-TV]] (09/29/2014) A subsequent medical investigation determined that Traficant had not had a heart attack or seizure before the accident, and was not under the influence of drugs or alcohol. In addition, he had not sustained any crushing injuries in the accident.{{cite news |title=Former Rep. Traficant didn't have heart attack, seizure before tractor death, pathologist says |url=https://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2014/09/former_rep_traficant_didnt_have_heart_attack_seizure.html |work=The Plain Dealer |agency=Associated Press |date=September 30, 2014}} The forensic pathologist who conducted the examination attributed Traficant's death to positional asphyxiation, stating that he had been unable to breathe because of the weight of the tractor, under which he had been trapped after the accident. == Publications == * {{cite book | last = Traficant | first = James | title = America's Last Minuteman | publisher = Sports Calendar International | location = New York | year = 2011 | isbn = 978-1-889036-01-4 }} * ''Target: Traficant, The Untold Story'', Michael Collins Piper, American Free Press; (2005); {{ISBN|978-0981808611}} ==See also== * [[List of United States Representatives from Ohio]] * [[List of United States Representatives expelled, censured, or reprimanded]] * [[List of American federal politicians convicted of crimes]] * [[List of federal political scandals in the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Wikiquote}} * {{Wikisource author-inline}} {{CongLinks|congbio=T000350}} * {{C-SPAN|jamestraficant}} * [http://www.cnn.com/2002/LAW/08/01/congress.traficant "Look at what Traficant swept under the rug"] – [[CNN]], August 1, 2002 * [http://www.criticalpast.com/video/65675034000_football-match_Pittsburgh-Panthers_Pitt-Scuttles-of-Navy_spectators-watch-the-match Traficant quarterbacking Pitt over Navy] * Official Website by Nicky Nelson & Jim Condit Jr., [http://www.projectfreedomusa.org/ Project Freedom USA]   * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7IV48Hf9YbY James Traficant - A Tribute] (Video) by Mike Wayne {{S-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Ohio | district=17 | before=[[Lyle Williams]] | after= vacancy, then [[Tim Ryan (politician)|Tim Ryan]] | years=January 3, 1985 – revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Kenji Nagai
{{lang|ja|長井 健司}} |image= Nagaikenji.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date|1957|8|27|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Imabari, Ehime]], [[Japan]] | age = | death_date = {{death date and age|2007|9|27|1957|8|27|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Yangon]], [[Myanmar]] | occupation = [[Photojournalism|Photojournalist]] | alias = | status = | title = | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | salary = | networth = | known_for = Being the only foreign national killed in the [[Saffron Revolution]]. | URL = | agent = }} {{nihongo|'''Kenji Nagai'''|長井 健司|Nagai Kenji|August 27, 1957 – September 27, 2007}} was a [[Japan]]ese [[Photojournalism|photojournalist]] who took many assignments to conflict zones and dangerous areas around the world. He was shot dead in Myanmar (also known as Burma) during the [[Saffron Revolution]]. Nagai continued to take photos as he lay wounded on the ground, later dying from [[Ballistic trauma|gunshot injuries]] to the chest. He was the only foreign national killed in the protests.{{cite news |title=Japanese journalist first foreign victim of Myanmar clashes |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-28 |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i9njHm47JNdhFWGOlyGw15TuDTZw |accessdate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080601225659/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i9njHm47JNdhFWGOlyGw15TuDTZw |archivedate=2008-06-01 |df= }} == Background == Kenji Nagai grew up in [[Imabari, Ehime]], Japan, and graduated from Imabari Nishi High School. Nagai attended [[Tokyo Keizai University]] ([[:ja:東京経済大学|東京経済大学]]), and after graduation he studied abroad in the [[United States]] for a year. After his return to Japan, Nagai held a part-time job before embarking upon his career as a [[Freelancer|freelance]] [[journalist]].{{cite news | title = Nagai's friends struggle for words | publisher = ''[[The Daily Yomiuri]]'' | date= 2007-09-29 | url = http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070929TDY02006.htm | accessdate = 2007-09-29 }} Working as a contract photojournalist for [[Tokyo]]'s AFP News, Nagai was accustomed to traveling to dangerous places in the [[Middle East]]. From 1997 until his death, Nagai took assignments in [[Afghanistan]], [[Cambodia]], the [[Palestinian territories]], and [[Iraq]], taking photographs that captured the essence of war.{{cite news | last = Chu | first = Henry | title = Protests persist despite bloodshed | work = Business: Technology | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date= 2007-09-28 | url = http://www.latimes.com/technology/la-fg-myanmar28sep28,1,1901803.story?coll=la-headlines-technology | accessdate = 2007-09-30 }} Nagai arrived in Myanmar two days before the government began attacking [[Bhikkhu|Buddhist monks]] protesting against the [[military junta]] that has ruled the country since deposing the democratic government in a [[Post-independence Burma, 1948-1962|1962 coup d'état]].{{cite news | title = Myanmar Troops Kill 9 More Protesters | publisher = [[Associated Press]] | date= 2007-09-27 | url = http://www.philly.com/philly/wires/ap/news/world/20070927_ap_myanmartroopskill9moreprotesters.html | accessdate = 2007-09-29 }} The protests originally began when the government raised the price of fuel, but grew into mass demonstrations in the tens of thousands, with Buddhist monks leading pro-democracy marches in the streets of [[Yangon]].{{cite news | title = Troops take back control in Myanmar | publisher = [[Associated Press]] | date= 2007-09-29 | url = https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070928/ap_on_re_as/myanmar | accessdate = 2007-09-29 }} According to ''[[The Times]]'', an associate of Nagai's said he was "relentless" when it came to covering a story, believing that he had to travel to "the places nobody wants to go." == Death == Nagai had been in Myanmar covering the anti-government protests since Tuesday, September 25. On Thursday, September 27, Nagai was photographing the protests near the [[Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts|Traders Hotel]], a few blocks away from the [[Sule Pagoda]] in downtown Yangon, when soldiers opened fire on demonstrators, killing Nagai and reportedly injuring another foreign journalist.{{cite press release |title=Japanese photographer killed, another foreign journalist injured |publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] |date=2007-09-27 |url=http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=23790 |accessdate=2007-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071003025225/http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=23790 |archivedate=2007-10-03 |df= }}{{cite news | title = Japan inquiry into reporter death | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date= 2007-09-28 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7017636.stm | accessdate = 2007-09-29 }} Reports initially stated that Nagai was hit by stray bullets fired by soldiers or possibly shot from the front. The "stray bullet" explanation was proposed by the [[Politics of Myanmar|government of Myanmar]] as an explanation for Nagai's death. However, video footage obtained by Japanese television appears to show a [[Myanmar Armed Forces|Burmese soldier]] shoving Nagai to the ground and shooting him at [[point-blank range]].{{cite news | title = Video shows Japanese journalist 'being shot deliberately' | publisher = [[Times Online]] | date= 2007-09-28 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article2550369.ece | accessdate = 2007-09-28 | location=London | first1=Leo | last1=Lewis}} A still image photographed by Adrees Latif showed the soldier standing over Nagai, who was sprawled on the ground and still clutching his camera. This photograph appeared on the front page of ''[[The New York Times]]'' on September 28, 2007. A subsequent shot showed Nagai's body sprawled in the street as the soldier walked away. Judging from the patch, the soldier responsible is believed to be from one of the [[Myanmar Army#Light Infantry Divisions .28LID.29|Light Infantry Divisions]] (possibly LID 66) in charge of crowd control in [[Yangon]] at the time of protests.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} At the Japanese embassy in Myanmar, a physician established the trajectory of the fatal bullet that killed Nagai, determining that the bullet entered Nagai's chest from the lower right side and pierced his heart before exiting from his back. On October 8, new footage showing how a Burmese soldier apparently confiscating a fallen Nagai's video camera was revealed on a Japanese news show.{{cite news |title = New footage of journalist shot in Burma shows soldier leaving scene with camera |work = |publisher = ''[[Japan News Review]]'' |date = 2007-10-09 |url = http://www.japannewsreview.com/society/international/20071009page_id=2350 |accessdate = 2007-10-09 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071025135728/http://www.japannewsreview.com/society/international/20071009page_id=2350 |archive-date = 2007-10-25 |dead-url = yes |df = }}{{cite news |title=ミャンマー：警官カメラ持ち去る…長井さん銃撃直後の映像 |work= |publisher=''[[Mainichi Shimbun]]'' |date=2007-10-09 |url=http://mainichi.jp/select/jiken/news/20071009k0000m030097000c.html |accessdate=2007-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011024558/http://mainichi.jp/select/jiken/news/20071009k0000m030097000c.html |archivedate=2007-10-11 |df= }} Adrees Latif's photo, depicting Nagai sprawling on the pavement before his death, won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography]] in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2008_4545647|title=Reuters photographer's risky shot wins Pulitzer|publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]]|first=Jennifer|last=Latson|date=2008-04-08|accessdate=2008-04-24|quote=His photograph of the fatal shooting of a fellow journalist, the Japanese videographer Kenji Nagai, won the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography on Monday.}} === Response === [[Reporters Without Borders]] condemned the killing of Nagai, noting that Nagai was carrying a camera in his hand when he was shot, identifying him as a journalist. The director of the RWB's [[Washington, D.C.]] branch, Lucie Morillon, said that Nagai was "left to die in the street."{{cite news | last = Gittens | first = Hasani | title = Shocking Fotog-Slay | publisher = [[New York Post]] | date= 2007-09-28 | url = http://www.nypost.com/seven/09282007/news/worldnews/shocking_fotog_slay.htm | accessdate = 2007-09-28 }} Japanese Prime Minister [[Yasuo Fukuda]] bemoaned Nagai's death as "extremely unfortunate" and Chief Cabinet Secretary [[Nobutaka Machimura]] offered his prayers and condolences. Machimura said: "We strongly protest the Myanmar government and demand an investigation (into the death). We demand (Myanmar) take appropriate steps to ensure the safety of the Japanese citizens in that country."{{cite news | title = 9 Killed in 2nd Day of Myanmar Crackdown | publisher = [[Associated Press]] | date= 2007-09-27 | url = | accessdate = }} Japan's Foreign Minister [[Masahiko Kōmura]] stated that Japan holds Myanmar accountable for the death of Kenji Nagai. According to Kōmura, U.S. Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] told him that the "international community cannot allow peaceful protesters to be killed and injured". On September 28, Masahiko Kōmura lodged a protest over the killing of Nagai when he met with Myanmar's Foreign Minister [[Nyan Win]] at the [[United Nations Headquarters]]. In the meeting, Nyan Win apologized for Nagai's death. Yabunaka Mitoji, Deputy Minister for Japanese Foreign Affairs, left for Myanmar on September 30.{{cite news |title=Deputy foreign minister leaves for Myanmar following journalist killing |work=National News |publisher=''[[Mainichi Daily News]]'' |date=2007-09-30 |url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/national/news/20070930p2a00m0na004000c.html |accessdate=2007-10-01 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Although Nyan Win officially apologized, an October 13 article locally published in the government-owned ''Mirror'' newspaper offered a different view of the events. It claimed that Nagai had entered the country using a tourist visa instead of proper journalist visa and faulted the cameraman for failing to get a permit to cover the news inside Myanmar. It emphasized that the event occurred at the time of martial law being imposed and the soldiers could not differentiate between a Burmese citizen and a Japanese because of the resemblance in Asian looks.{{cite news |title=Prevent salt destroying the Soup (Pyipannyo cho chin lyet, Sarr ka ma phyet aung) |publisher=The Mirror |date=2007-10-13 |author=Kyaw Min Lu (Shwe Pyi Thar) |language=Burmese |page=6 and 7 |url=http://www.mrtv3.net.mm/newpaper/1310newsk.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061023125342/http://www.mrtv3.net.mm/newpaper/1310newsk.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-10-23 |accessdate=2007-10-13 }} Nagai's father, Hideo, told the media: "I don't want Myanmar authorities and the government to resort to such measures. I want them to prevent something like this from happening again."{{cite news |title=Japan to demand full explanation of death of journalist in Myanmar |publisher=[[Canadian Press]] |date=2007-09-29 |url=http://canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5jUhofNCS4X5xhVKlzroIIGpofk2A |accessdate=2007-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024143808/http://canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5jUhofNCS4X5xhVKlzroIIGpofk2A |archivedate=2007-10-24 |df= }} According to Japan's Foreign minister Masahiko Komura, Japan is considered curbing development aid for Myanmar.[[Der Spiegel]]: [http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,509272,00.html Massenverhaftungen in Burma - Major verweigert Schießbefehl], October 3, 2007AP: [http://www.bma-online.org/BMW_2007_Sep_Dec.html#0 AP - Japan may cut aid to Myanmar to protest fatal shooting of Japanese journalist] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024145609/http://bma-online.org/BMW_2007_Sep_Dec.html |date=2007-10-24 }}, October 3, 2007 "The Group Protesting the Murder of Mr. Nagai by the Army of Myanmar" was founded by Japanese journalists, intellectuals and celebrities in order to protest Nagai's killing and petition for the return of his camera and tape. By November 2007 the group collected 20,000 signatures, primarily in Japan. On November 26, 2007, the group posted an English version of the letter on their website and started collecting signatures internationally.{{cite news | title = Protest Statement (the Murder of Nagai in Myanmar ) | publisher = | date= | author = | url = http://blog.goo.ne.jp/nagaikenji20070927/e/2f627ce42b5fbd7466f1506a50ac3b3d | accessdate = 2007-12-24 }} == Kenji Nagai Award == The [[Burma Media Association]] established an award in Nagai's memory. The award aims to recognize individuals who have reported the truth about Myanmar. The first award, in 2009, was presented to Eint Khaing Oo, a Burmese female journalist.{{cite news|title=Myanmar woman to get Nagai award|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2009/02/15/national/myanmar-woman-to-get-nagai-award/|publisher=[[Kyodo News]]|date=February 15, 2009}} == See also == * [[International reaction to the 2007 Burmese anti-government protests]] * [[Hiro Muramoto]], cameraman and journalist shot by a soldier in Bangkok, 2010 * [[Lucas Dolega]], photojournalist shot by police in Tunis, 2012 == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|Kenji Nagai}} {{Wikinews|Japanese journalist shot and killed in Myanmar}} * [http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/20070929TDY02006.htm Nagai's friends struggle for words] * [http://blog.goo.ne.jp/nagaikenji20070927/e/2f627ce42b5fbd7466f1506a50ac3b3d The Group Protesting the Murder of Mr. Nagai by the Army of Myanmar] === Video === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927144416/http://www.apfnews.com/video/iraq1mac.asx The documentary picture of the Iraqi War by Nagai. Part 1 (video)] - [http://www.apfnews.com/ APF通信社] * [http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x3302m_kenji-nagai-shot-by-burmese-soldier_news Kenji Nagai shot by Burmese soldiers (video)] at [[Dailymotion]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nagai, Kenji}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Japanese photojournalists]] [[Category:Japanese war correspondents]] [[Category:Agence France-Presse photojournalists]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Myanmar]] [[Category:Filmed assassinations]] [[Category:Japanese people murdered abroad]] [[Category:Japanese people of the Iraq War]] [[Category:War photographers killed while covering military conflicts]] [[Category:Murder in 2007]] [[Category:People from Ehime Prefecture]] [[Category:People murdered in Myanmar]] [[Category:Photography in Myanmar]] [[Category:Protest-related deaths]] [[Category:War correspondents of the Iraq War]] [[Category:Assassinated Japanese journalists]]

revision.comment: BOT--Reverting link addition(s) by [[:en:Special:Contributions/117.214.238.149|117.214.238.149]] to revision 871665334 (www.youtube.com/channel/UCkH_cVFZrn7q87a0Pbsmx3Q [\byoutube\.com])
